texts.shortText:
Members of the family Arcturidae are unusual, isopods that have elongate bodies that are usually bent between the thorax and abdomen. The antennae are often very long and the second to fourth pairs of walking limbs elongate and setose for filter-feeding, while the last three pairs are much shorter and adapted for clinging. The fourth thoracic segment is often greatly elongated and/or laterally expanded.

This species has a greatly expanded fourth thoracic segment that is raised posteriorly into a large, blunt, upright projection. The colour pattern is also distinctive as both the elongate, robust antennae and the enlarged triangular thoracic segment are dark red-brown and the rest of the body white. Although several species in this genus are known from South Africa, this species appears to be new to science.

Global: Endemic.

Local/Regional: Known only from the collections site at Kommetjie on the Cape Peninsula.

This specimen was found under a boulder in an intertidal rock pool but members of this group are typically associated with hydroids, bryozoans, octocorals and other sedentary invertebrates, to which they cling, extending the front part of the body into the water column to filer feed.
Presumed to be a filter-feeder, like most other members of this family, grasping floating particles with the setose anterior limbs.
As with all isopods, the eggs are retained in a marsupial pouch between the walking legs of females, where they develop into fully-formed young prior to release.

This species appears to be undescribed, although six other members of this genus are known from the region (described and depicted in Kensley 1978 under the generic name Arcturella, which has now been incorporated within Astacilla).

Kensley, B (1978). Guide to the Marine Isopods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p. 19 â€“ this species not featured but several others in the genus depicted as Arcturella species).

Kensley, BF & Schotte, M (1984). Redescription of Arcturella lineata (Stebbing) from South Africa (Crustacea: Isopoda: Arcturidae). Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington, 97(1), 240-244.
